in cats:
    ◦ Gastrointestinal Irritation: Unlike true lilies (Lilium spp.) that cause kidney failure, Gladioli primarily cause severe irritation to the digestive tract. This leads to symptoms such as salivation (drooling), vomiting, and diarrhea.

toxins.concentration_notes:
◦ Highest Concentration in Bulbs: The bulb (also known as the corm) is the most toxic part of the plant.
    ◦ Severity: While considered generally less dangerous than true lilies, ingestion can still cause significant discomfort and severe gastrointestinal upset.• 11 popular plants and flowers poisonous to cats - Vets Now1
• Outdoor Plants That Are Toxic to Cats: 10 to Avoid (Vet-Reviewed) - Catster2
• Houseplants and Ornamentals Toxic to Animals - Toxicology - Merck Veterinary Manual

symptoms.name: Vomiting and Diarrhea (Gastrointestinal Upset)
symptoms.onset: Acute (Typically within a few hours of ingestion).
symptoms.notes: Ingestion of any part of the plant can cause these symptoms, but the bulb (corm) is the most toxic part and causes the most severe reactions.Excessive Drooling (Hypersalivation)

symptoms.name: Drooling / Salivation
symptoms.notes: This occurs due to the plant's irritant properties on the mouth and digestive tract. Gladioli belong to the Iridaceae (Iris) family, which are known to cause oral and mucosal irritation when eaten.Lethargy

symptoms.name: Lethargy
symptoms.notes: The cat may appear tired or disinterested in food due to the abdominal discomfort and nausea associated with the poisoning.Abdominal Pain

symptoms.name: Abdominal Pain
symptoms.notes: Often described as "stomach upset" or discomfort. Because Gladioli are in the same family as Irises, symptoms can overlap, including general abdominal tenderness.

treatments.name: Pharmacological Symptom Management (Anti-emetics and Antidiarrheals)
treatments.description: Veterinarians administer medications to control the primary symptoms of poisoning. Anti-emetics are given to stop vomiting, and antidiarrheals are used to manage diarrhea. A bland diet may be prescribed for several days to soothe the digestive tract during recovery.
treatments.notes: Because Gladioli act primarily as gastrointestinal irritants, the goal is to stabilize the cat and prevent further fluid loss. Most animals recover within 24–48 hours with this support.Fluid Therapy

treatments.name: Intravenous (IV) or Subcutaneous Fluid Administration
treatments.description: If the cat has experienced significant vomiting or diarrhea, the veterinarian will administer fluids to correct dehydration and restore electrolyte balance.
treatments.notes: This is particularly important if the cat is lethargic or has been unable to keep water down. Maintaining hydration helps flush toxins and supports general organ function.Gastrointestinal Decontamination (Emesis)

treatments.name: Induction of Emesis (Vomiting)
treatments.description: If the ingestion was very recent (typically within 1–2 hours) and the cat is asymptomatic, the veterinarian may induce vomiting to remove the plant material (especially the toxic bulbs) from the stomach before the toxins are fully absorbed.
treatments.notes: This should never be attempted at home using hydrogen peroxide, as it can cause severe irritation and injury to cats. It must be performed by a veterinary professional.Oral Decontamination and Soothing

treatments.name: Oral Rinsing and Demulcents
treatments.description: If the cat is drooling excessively or showing signs of oral irritation (common with plants in the Iridaceae family), the vet may rinse the mouth to remove plant residue. They may also administer demulcents (soothing agents) or dairy products (like milk) to bind crystals and soothe the mucous membranes.
treatments.notes: While less common for Gladioli than for plants with insoluble oxalates (like Dieffenbachia), oral irritation can occur.
